solution_line_template: First find how much money the ex made during the first {first_period_years} years by multiplying his annual earnings by the number of years: {first_period_years} years * ${initial_annual_income}/year = $<<{first_period_years}*{initial_annual_income}={income_first_period}>>{income_first_period}/

Then find how much his raise was by multiplying his salary by the percentage raise: ${initial_annual_income}/year * {raise_percent}% = $<<{initial_annual_income}*{raise_percent}*{percent_to_decimal_factor}={raise_amount}>>{raise_amount}/year

Then add the raise to his original salary to find his new salary: ${raise_amount}/year + ${initial_annual_income}/year = $<<{raise_amount}+{initial_annual_income}={new_annual_income}>>{new_annual_income}/year

Then find how much he made working at the new salary by multiplying it by the {second_period_years} years he worked: {second_period_years} years * ${new_annual_income}/year = $<<{second_period_years}*{new_annual_income}={income_second_period}>>{income_second_period}

Add his earnings from the three years and the four years to find his total earnings: ${income_second_period} + ${income_first_period} = $<<{income_second_period}+{income_first_period}={total_earnings}>>{total_earnings}

Now multiply his total earnings by {child_support_percent}% to find how much he was supposed to pay: ${total_earnings} * {child_support_percent}% = $<<{total_earnings}*{child_support_percent}*{percent_to_decimal_factor}={total_supposed_to_pay}>>{total_supposed_to_pay}
Now subtract the amount he paid from this number to find how much he owes: ${total_supposed_to_pay} - ${amount_paid} = $<<{total_supposed_to_pay}-{amount_paid}={amount_owed}>>{amount_owed}
